study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary strawberry supplementation impacts cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors due to their high oxidant and micronutrient content.
results_summary: Strawberry supplementation was found to decrease circulating oxidized LDL levels, indicating a potential benefit for cardiovascular health. The study pooled data from 14 clinical trials, suggesting a statistically significant effect.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from CVD risk focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the medicinal benefits of chlorogenic acid (CGA), including its presence in strawberries, and emphasize its anti-obesity properties.
results_summary: The study highlights that CGA, found in minor quantities in strawberries, exhibits antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and anti-obesity effects by activating AMP-activated protein kinase and inhibiting key metabolic enzymes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of scientific reports).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the available literature on Chilean strawberries (Fragaria chiloensis) to assess their physiology, quality, health benefits, and postharvest handling challenges.
results_summary: The study highlights Chilean strawberries as a functional food with high phenolic content and potential preventive and therapeutic health benefits, though information on quality, handling, and storage remains limited.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for determining folate bioavailability in plasma and assess the relative bioavailability of folates from strawberries in humans.
results_summary: The study validated a sensitive method for quantifying folates in plasma and demonstrated high recovery (96.2% relative bioavailability) of strawberry folates in human metabolism. The method was also applicable for monitoring post-absorptive plasma folate levels and screening individual folate status.
population_specificity: Human participants (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of L-ascorbic acid (with hydrate from strawberries) in combination with no-needle and micro-needle mesotherapy for anti-aging therapy.
results_summary: Both no-needle and micro-needle mesotherapy methods were effective, but micro-needle mesotherapy showed superior results in improving skin firmness, elasticity, hydration, and tone.
population_specificity: 17 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: 2.5 ml of serum containing 20% L-ascorbic acid with hydrate from strawberries, applied topically in each of 4 treatments

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential protective role of strawberries and other fruits in reducing pain and inflammation in arthritis, particularly osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found that strawberries, along with other fruits like blueberries and pomegranates, showed promising results in reducing pain and inflammation in both experimental models and human clinical studies of arthritis. Specific polyphenols, such as quercetin, were also noted for alleviating RA symptoms.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteoarthritis (OA) and rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate strawberries and other berries for their potential medicinal properties, focusing on their bioactive compounds and therapeutic effects against chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that strawberries, rich in polyphenols, exhibit potential pharmacological benefits by targeting oxidative stress and inflammation, which are linked to diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer. However, future clinical trials are needed to confirm these effects and improve bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on berries' effects in chronic diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of milk and mixed nutrient meals on the oral bioavailability and pharmacokinetic variables of strawberry anthocyanins.
results_summary: Beverages prepared in milk significantly reduced peak plasma concentrations of strawberry anthocyanins, independent of meal consumption. The study suggests that dietary factors like milk may influence anthocyanin bioavailability.
population_specificity: Nine healthy participants (with a subset of four for additional testing).
interactions: Milk was noted to potentially reduce anthocyanin bioavailability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of daily consumption of freeze-dried strawberry powder on blood pressure and arterial stiffness in pre- and stage 1-hypertensive postmenopausal women.
results_summary: After eight weeks, systolic blood pressure and arterial stiffness (measured by pulse wave velocity) were significantly reduced in the group consuming 25 g of freeze-dried strawberry powder daily. No significant changes were reported for the control group.
population_specificity: Pre- and stage 1-hypertensive postmenopausal women (n=60).
effective_dosage: 25 g and 50 g of freeze-dried strawberry powder daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological effects, therapeutic activities, and analytical techniques related to agrimoniin, a compound found in strawberries and other Rosaceae plants.
results_summary: The study highlights that agrimoniin, present in strawberries, is metabolized into bioactive urolithins with anti-inflammatory and anticancer properties, supported by in vivo and in vitro evidence. The abstract suggests potential therapeutic benefits but does not provide specific clinical outcomes for strawberries alone.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human consumption and gut microbiota metabolism discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how serum hippuric acid changes after a diet including strawberries (among other berries) and its association with insulin and glucose metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that fasting serum hippuric acid did not significantly increase in the strawberry, raspberry, and cloudberry (SRC) group, unlike the bilberry group. The SRC diet (lower anthocyanin intake) did not show significant correlations with glycemic control or insulin secretion.
population_specificity: 47 individuals with features of metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of strawberry and cranberry polyphenols on insulin sensitivity, glucose tolerance, and other cardiometabolic risk factors in insulin-resistant overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that a 6-week dietary intervention with strawberry and cranberry polyphenols improved insulin sensitivity but did not significantly affect other cardiometabolic risk factors like lipids, inflammation, or oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese, non-diabetic, insulin-resistant human subjects (n=41).
effective_dosage: 333 mg of strawberry and cranberry polyphenols daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if consuming strawberries at different times relative to a meal influences meal-induced oxidative-immuno-metabolic outcomes, particularly glycemic control and inflammation.
results_summary: Consuming strawberries before a meal significantly reduced postprandial glucose and interleukin-6 levels compared to consuming them with the meal or not at all, suggesting improved insulin sensitivity and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Fourteen overweight healthy adults.
effective_dosage: Strawberry drink provided at one of three time points (2 hours before, with, or 2 hours after a meal).
study_duration: Blood samples were collected over 10 hours per study visit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding freeze-dried strawberry powder to a high-fat meal improves postprandial vascular function and metabolic responses (triglycerides, glucose, insulin).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the strawberry and control meals in vascular function or metabolic responses. Both meals similarly decreased augmentation index and increased triglycerides, insulin, and glucose postprandially.
population_specificity: Healthy, overweight or obese adults (mean BMI 30.3 ± 0.5).
effective_dosage: 40 g freeze-dried strawberry powder (~1 lb. fresh strawberries) with a high-fat meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory and disease-preventive effects of fisetin, a flavonoid found in strawberries and other fruits, against chronic inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: The study found that fisetin, present in strawberries, exhibits strong anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and protective effects against various chronic diseases, including neurological, cardiovascular, and metabolic disorders, based on cell culture and animal models.
population_specificity: Animal models and cell cultures relevant to human diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer effects of fisetin, a flavonol found in strawberries and other fruits, and assess its potential therapeutic role in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that fisetin inhibits or retards the growth of various cancer cells in culture and implanted tumors in vivo by targeting intracellular signaling pathways related to cell survival, apoptosis, angiogenesis, and metastasis. Current evidence supports fisetin as a promising agent for cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies, not human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the health benefits of strawberries, focusing on their bioactive compounds and their effects on various pathologies.
results_summary: The study found that strawberries contain bioactive compounds that may help prevent inflammation, oxidative stress, obesity-related disorders, heart disease, and cancer. The review highlighted their potential benefits in combating metabolic syndrome, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, neurodegeneration, and microbial infections.
population_specificity: Human studies (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and discuss the anti-cancer properties of fisetin, a flavonol found in strawberries and other fruits, focusing on its molecular mechanisms and potential as a chemopreventive/chemotherapeutic agent.
results_summary: Fisetin demonstrated anti-microbial, anti-inflammatory, anti-oxidant, and notably anti-carcinogenic activity in various cell culture and animal models, with observed growth inhibitory effects in different cancer cell types. The study highlights its potential as a therapeutic alternative against cancer but calls for further research to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models (cell cultures and animal systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and discuss the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which strawberry polyphenols exert beneficial effects against chronic diseases such as cancer, cardiovascular diseases, metabolic syndrome, and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that strawberry consumption is associated with anti-inflammatory, anticarcinogenic, and antiproliferative effects, improves plasma antioxidant capacity, reduces chronic inflammation, and enhances cardiovascular health, particularly in individuals at risk for metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Individuals with increased risk for metabolic syndrome and chronic-degenerative diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic fate of strawberry polyphenols after chronic supplementation of freeze-dried strawberries.
results_summary: The study found that strawberry polyphenols are absorbed and metabolized into various phenolic metabolites/conjugates in the body, which may contribute to disease risk reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
effective_dosage: 24 g per day of freeze-dried strawberry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a berry mixture (including strawberries) on serum lipid profiles, gut microbiota, and ellagitannin metabolites in individuals with metabolic syndrome symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that the bioavailability of ellagitannins from the berry mixture depends on gut microbiota composition, suggesting a potential link between berry consumption and metabolic health through microbial activity.
population_specificity: Individuals with symptoms of metabolic syndrome

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate how applied sensory testing can be used in plant breeding research on strawberries to align sensory properties with consumer expectations.
results_summary: The abstract mentions a case study where applied sensory techniques were used in strawberry plant breeding research, but specific results regarding strawberries' effects are not detailed. The focus was on achieving sensory congruence rather than measuring efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of freeze-dried strawberry supplementation on glycemic control, oxidative stress, inflammation, and antioxidant status in subjects with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Freeze-dried strawberry supplementation significantly reduced inflammation (C-reactive protein) and lipid peroxidation (MDA), improved antioxidant status, and showed a trend toward better glycemic control (HbA1c) in type 2 diabetes patients. No significant changes were observed in serum glucose or anthropometric indices.
population_specificity: 36 subjects with type 2 diabetes (23 females; mean BMI 27.90 ± 3.7; mean age 51.57 ± 10 years).
effective_dosage: 50 g of freeze-dried strawberries (equivalent to 500 g fresh strawberries) daily in beverage form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the nutritional and phytochemical composition of strawberries and their potential biological activity on human health, focusing on absorption, metabolism, and health benefits.
results_summary: The abstract highlights strawberries' high content of essential nutrients and beneficial phytochemicals like anthocyanins and ellagitannins, which have antioxidant properties. However, human intervention studies using whole strawberries are still lacking, limiting definitive conclusions on their biological activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of freeze-dried strawberry powder on reducing dysplastic esophageal premalignant lesions in a high-risk population for esophageal cancer.
results_summary: The 60 g/d dose significantly reduced histologic grade in 80.6% of patients, lowered inflammatory markers (iNOS, COX-2, pNFκB-p65, pS6), and inhibited cell proliferation (Ki-67). The 30 g/d dose showed no significant effects.
population_specificity: Patients with dysplastic esophageal premalignant lesions in a high-risk area for esophageal cancer (China).
effective_dosage: 30 g/d and 60 g/d, mixed with water and consumed daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lycopene, found in strawberries among other foods, reduces the incidence of prostate cancer and prostate cancer-specific mortality.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to support or refute lycopene's effectiveness in preventing prostate cancer, with no significant difference in PSA levels or lycopene levels between groups. Only one study reported prostate cancer incidence, showing a lower rate in the lycopene group (10%) versus control (30%).
population_specificity: Men, primarily focusing on prostate cancer risk or related outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of nerve stretching beyond 5% of its resting length and its association with neuropathy symptoms in a specific patient case.
results_summary: The study found that excessive nerve stretching led to symptoms like numbness, pain, and tingling, which recurred over time. The patient's condition improved but remained unresolved after 12 months of follow-up.
population_specificity: 55-year-old male with no significant past medical history, experiencing left upper extremity symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether stretching-dehydration (SD) processing could enhance the mechanical properties and anisotropy of polysaccharide-based hydrogels to mimic whole-muscle food textures.
results_summary: The study found that SD processing improved anisotropy, stretching strength, and Young's modulus in hydrogels, particularly in low molecular weight sodium alginate (SA-L), achieving up to 100 MPa. Sensory evaluations indicated enhanced chewiness and hardness, suggesting potential for whole-muscle food emulation.
population_specificity: Polysaccharide-based hydrogels (sodium alginate, pectin, gellan gum, curdlan).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cardiovascular benefits of strawberries and other berries, focusing on their effects on LDL oxidation, lipid peroxidation, antioxidant capacity, dyslipidemia, and glucose metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that strawberries, along with other berries, significantly improved cardiovascular risk markers, including LDL oxidation, lipid peroxidation, and glucose metabolism, in both healthy subjects and those with metabolic risk factors. The benefits were attributed to mechanisms like reduced oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and individuals with existing metabolic risk factors.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fresh, juice, or freeze-dried forms mentioned, but exact dosages not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of an individually tailored dynamic stretching program compared to usual care for improving functional mobility in ambulant children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study is ongoing (SPELL trial), so results are not yet available. It will compare functional mobility, joint range of motion, motor function, and other secondary outcomes between the dynamic stretching program and usual care at six and 12 months.
population_specificity: Ambulant children aged four to 11 years with spastic cerebral palsy (bilateral or unilateral) and GMFCS levels I to III.
effective_dosage: Six one-to-one physiotherapy sessions over 16 weeks for the intervention group.
study_duration: 16 weeks (intervention), with follow-up at six and 12 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of stretching and tissue release interventions in managing neck pain and muscle fatigue in office workers with nonspecific chronic neck pain.
results_summary: Both stretching and tissue release interventions significantly reduced neck pain after 6 weeks. Stretching showed specific benefits in the left sternocleidomastoid muscle at early time points, while tissue release was more effective in reducing fatigue in cervical and upper trapezius muscles at later time points.
population_specificity: Office workers suffering from nonspecific chronic neck pain (n=39).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effects of conventional self-stretching and weight-bearing stretching on the stiffness of the flexor digitorum longus (FDL) and tibialis posterior (TP) muscles.
results_summary: Weight-bearing stretching significantly reduced the shear modulus (indicating reduced stiffness) of the FDL compared to baseline and the control trial, while conventional self-stretching showed no significant effect. No significant changes were observed in the TP muscle stiffness for either stretching method.
population_specificity: 13 healthy men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding bilateral hamstring stretching to pressure pain threshold and ultrasound therapy improves pain reduction and maximum vertical mouth opening in individuals with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) compared to using pressure pain threshold and ultrasound therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found that hamstring stretching combined with ultrasound therapy and pressure pain threshold application significantly reduced pain and improved maximum vertical mouth opening more effectively than the control treatment. The Experimental Group showed greater improvements in both pain reduction and functional outcomes compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 18-35 years diagnosed with TMD and a history of TMD pain lasting no longer than 6 months.
effective_dosage: 5 treatment sessions per week (specific stretching duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mechanical percussive massage therapy versus static stretching on improving passive knee extension range of motion in the hamstrings.
results_summary: Both mechanical percussive massage therapy and static stretching significantly increased passive knee extension range of motion compared to the control group, with no significant difference between the two treatments. The control group showed no meaningful change.
population_specificity: Male collegiate football players (NCAA Division III and NAIA Division II, mean age 19.8 years).
effective_dosage: Static stretching involved 3 repetitions of 30 seconds with 10-second rest intervals.
study_duration: Single session (5 minutes for percussive massage, 3x30s for stretching).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of acute and chronic static stretching on stretch tolerance, passive stiffness, and fascicle length, and whether these effects are influenced by training parameters and participant characteristics.
results_summary: Both acute and chronic static stretching reduced overall stiffness, while only chronic stretching increased stretch tolerance. Neither acute nor chronic stretching altered fascicle length, and improved range of motion was associated with decreased stiffness and increased stretch tolerance after chronic stretching.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years (71% male; mean age = 26.1 ± 11 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intensity levels: low, moderate, high).
study_duration: Acute (single session) and chronic (two or more sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical feasibility and limitations of stretching the ligamentum teres hepatis (SLTH) as a surgical approach to improve exposure during laparoscopic right partial hepatectomy (LRPH).
results_summary: The study found that SLTH significantly reduced intraoperative blood loss, shortened the duration of hepatic parenchyma detachment and hepatic portal occlusion, and resulted in lower postoperative ALT and AST levels compared to the conventional approach (NSLTH). The technique was deemed simple, safe, effective, and highly reproducible for LRPH.
population_specificity: 276 patients with liver space-occupying lesions who underwent laparoscopic right partial hepatectomy (after PSM, 102 patients in each cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of flexibility or strengthening exercises, including stretching, in improving flexibility, strength, muscle architecture, and functional performance in older adults with leg tightness and/or suspected sarcopenia.
results_summary: All exercise groups showed improved mobility performance, strength, and flexibility, with strength-based programs providing additional benefits like short-lasting muscle hypertrophy. Hamstring flexibility increased in all groups except the resistance-band exercise group, and calf flexibility improved across all groups.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 66.8 ± 4.9 years) with leg tightness and/or suspected sarcopenia.
study_duration: Eight weeks, with a three-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of stretching exercises, alone and combined with PEMF, in treating muscle injuries by evaluating inflammatory markers and tissue healing.
results_summary: Stretching exercises, especially when combined with PEMF, reduced muscle degeneration, necrosis, and inflammatory markers (TGF-β1, eNOS) while promoting healing and preventing fibrosis. The INJ + Exercise + PEMF group showed the most balanced inflammatory response and improved muscle recovery.
population_specificity: Rats with induced muscle injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the effects of stretching exercises on health outcomes in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The review found that stretching exercises may influence various health parameters, including blood glucose regulation, functional capacity, plantar pressure, joint mobility, and fatigue in T2DM patients, but emphasized the need for further high-quality research.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week, home-based stretching program could improve symptoms in fibromyalgia patients compared to usual care.
results_summary: The study hypothesized that stretching would improve Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ-R) scores and other symptoms, but results were not yet reported as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: Adults under 65 years diagnosed with fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of static stretching on handgrip strength and wrist joint flexibility in older women.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in handgrip strength after static stretching but observed a significant increase in wrist joint range of motion. The results suggest that a 30-s bout of static stretching improves flexibility without compromising strength.
population_specificity: Twenty physically active older women (68 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of varying durations (40-, 80-, and 120-seconds) of antagonist static stretching on agonist muscle performance.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in plantar flexor performance across different stretching durations, but observed overall decreases in isokinetic peak torque, total work, and stiff leg drop jump measures, suggesting possible testing effects rather than stretching-specific impacts. Soleus EMG activity decreased post-stretching at longer durations (80-s and 120-s).
population_specificity: 16 participants (six females)
study_duration: Single sessions with pre- and post-intervention measurements

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the immediate effects of hamstring stretching alone or combined with myofascial release on masseter muscle activity, pain thresholds, flexibility, and posture in recreationally active participants.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in masseter muscle activity and knee extension flexibility, with mild enhancements in pain thresholds, but no significant effects on jaw opening or posture. Both treatment protocols (stretching alone and stretching with myofascial release) were equally effective.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy young adults aged 18-25 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Roxadustat (a hypoxia mimetic) with cyclic uniaxial stretching enhances tenogenic differentiation of adipose-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ADMSCs) for tendon repair.
results_summary: The combination of Roxadustat and uniaxial stretching (ROX+S group) significantly upregulated tenogenic markers (SCX, TNC, TNMD, COLI, COLIII) and HIF-1α expression, outperforming other treatments. Stretching also counteracted the inhibitory effects of the HIF-1α blocker CAY10585.
population_specificity: Adipose-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ADMSCs) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Cyclic uniaxial stretching at 1 Hz and 8% strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary strawberries (as freeze-dried powder) could beneficially alter lipid profiles and reduce blood markers of inflammation in obese subjects compared to a control intervention.
results_summary: A 3-week dietary intervention with strawberry powder reduced plasma cholesterol and small HDL-cholesterol particles while increasing LDL particle size in obese subjects, suggesting strawberries may lower risk factors for CVD, stroke, and diabetes.
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI 30-40 kg/m²), aged 20-50 years (13 females, 7 males).
effective_dosage: Equivalent to four servings of frozen strawberries daily.
study_duration: 3 weeks per intervention (total 7-week study with crossover design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how selective static stretching of the rectus femoris (RF) affects motor unit firing behaviors in both the RF and vastus lateralis (VL) muscles.
results_summary: Static stretching reduced RF stiffness but not VL stiffness. It also enhanced motor unit recruitment in the VL, though the effect was small, while no significant changes were observed in RF recruitment threshold, firing rates, or maximal strength.
population_specificity: 14 males (23.7 ± 2.4 years)
effective_dosage: 1-minute passive hip extension and knee flexion, repeated for 6 sets
study_duration: Single session (6 sets with unspecified rest intervals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of stretching exercise (STRETCH) versus eccentric resistance exercise (ECC) on cognitive and physical function in older women.
results_summary: Stretching showed no significant improvements in cognitive function tests (except for one-leg balance) compared to eccentric exercise, which demonstrated better outcomes in physical function tests and some cognitive measures.
population_specificity: Healthy older women aged 65-75 years.
effective_dosage: 12 stretching exercises, supervised sessions twice weekly with a home-based program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of foot intrinsic muscle dynamic stretching versus standard lunge exercise on balance and gait parameters in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Foot intrinsic muscle dynamic stretching significantly improved dynamic balance, gait velocity, step length, stride length, and the Dynamic Gait Index compared to baseline and standard lunge exercise.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=20, split into two groups of 10).
effective_dosage: 3 sets of 10 repetitions, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neural underpinnings and analgesic effects of resizing illusions (stretching/shrinking manipulations) in individuals with chronic pain.
results_summary: The study found no clear differences in SSEP amplitudes during illusory stretching and no significant overall pain reduction, though some participants experienced clinically meaningful pain relief. Subjective data confirmed stronger illusory effects in multisensory conditions, unrelated to limb disownership.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of breathing exercises alone versus combined breathing-stretching exercises on respiratory indices, disease severity, and exercise capacity in COPD patients.
results_summary: The study found that combined breathing-stretching exercises significantly improved PCO2, O2 saturation, disease severity, and 6-minute walk test scores compared to breathing exercises alone. The intervention group showed greater improvements in all measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 32 COPD patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intraoperative endoluminal pyloromyotomy (PM) was more effective than atraumatic stretching of the pylorus in reducing delayed gastric emptying (DGE) after pylorus-preserving partial pancreatoduodenectomy (ppPD).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in DGE rates between the PM group (62.5%) and the control group (56.3%), indicating that atraumatic stretching was as effective as PM. Complication rates and quality of life were similar between both groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing ppPD for tumors of the pancreatic head.
study_duration: Immediate intraoperative intervention with follow-up for 30 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how combining electrospinning with hot-stretching post-treatment affects the mechanical properties, fiber orientation, crystallinity, and biocompatibility of high-molecular-weight poly(l-lactic-acid) (hmwPLLA) electrospun nanofiber-constructed yarns (ENCYs).
results_summary: The study found that hot-stretching significantly improved fiber orientation, crystallinity, and mechanical properties of hmwPLLA ENCYs, with higher stretching rates further enhancing breaking strength and Young's modulus. Braided textiles made from stretched ENCYs exhibited excellent biocompatibility, supporting cell alignment, adhesion, and proliferation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on hmwPLLA materials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether stretching improves muscle anisotropy (measured via DTI parameters) in the quadriceps and its correlation with intramuscular adipose tissue (IntraMAT) ratios.
results_summary: Stretching acutely decreased λ1-3 and increased fractional anisotropy (FA) in the vastus medialis (VM), with changes in λ2, λ3, and FA significantly correlated with IntraMAT ratios, suggesting potential functional improvements, especially in overweight/obese individuals.
population_specificity: 20 young males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of PNF stretching on rectus femoris muscle stiffness and explore a potential dose-response relationship.
results_summary: PNF stretching had no statistically significant effect on muscle stiffness, with no differences between groups or over time. However, the proximal location of the muscle showed higher stiffness than the distal location, independent of the intervention.
population_specificity: Thirty healthy young adults (23 females, 7 males).
effective_dosage: Six sets, each with three 10-second stretches and 5-second maximal contractions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and test a soft, active stretching orthosis for at-home rehabilitation of upper-limb impairment in stroke or traumatic brain injury patients with spastic hands.
results_summary: The prototype orthosis successfully opened the hands of two patients (one stroke survivor, one traumatic brain injury survivor) consistently. Donning and doffing times were favorable compared to existing literature, and the device was designed with low-cost materials for home accessibility.
population_specificity: Stroke or traumatic brain injury patients with spastic (stiff, clenched) hands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether passive stretching with superimposed vibration (20 Hz) provides additional benefits in range of motion (ROM) and skin temperature compared to passive stretching alone in young athletes.
results_summary: Both stretching interventions (with and without vibration) significantly increased ROM compared to the control group, but vibration did not further enhance ROM. Skin temperature decreased in the control and stretching-only groups but remained constant with vibration. Stiffness was unaffected by either intervention.
population_specificity: Male Olympic youth skiing athletes (n = 8, age: 17.9 ± 1.0 years).
effective_dosage: Vibration frequency of 20 Hz during stretching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how polymer self-assembled morphologies, particularly non-spherical nanostructures like tubesomes, affect hydrogen sulfide (H2S) release capacity and its therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: Tubular polymersomes (tubesomes) showed enhanced cysteine-responsive H2S-releasing behavior compared to spherical polymersomes, with release kinetics dependent on membrane elongation. Tubesomes also demonstrated better anticancer performance than spherical counterparts.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of a self-modified skin-stretching device for treating soft-tissue defects in the heel.
results_summary: The study found that the self-modified skin-stretching device achieved wound closure in all patients, with good functional outcomes (average AOFAS score of 86.7) and low pain levels (mean VAS score of 2.6). Complications occurred in 9 patients, but all wounds eventually healed.
population_specificity: 23 patients (15 males, 8 females) with heel soft-tissue defects, aged 28-73 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of modified posterior shoulder stretching exercises in improving shoulder function and reducing pain in patients with subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS).
results_summary: The study found that modified posterior shoulder stretching exercises significantly reduced pain at rest and during activity, improved internal and external rotation range of motion, enhanced shoulder function, and reduced disability in patients with SIS. The results were robust with low risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with subacromial impingement syndrome (SIS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of fascia in tension transmission and propose a hypothesis on myofascial trigger points (MTrPs) development, while evaluating stretching techniques for addressing fascial dysfunctions.
results_summary: The study suggests that imbalanced tension loading on fascial components may lead to MTrPs and proposes stretching techniques to address excessive rigidity in the myofascial system. It also recommends integrating fascial training with other exercises to prevent and treat musculoskeletal disorders.
population_specificity: General human musculoskeletal system (no specific subpopulation mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate StretchView, a multi-axial cell-stretching platform compatible with automated live-cell imaging, to study mechanobiological responses of cells under stretch conditions.
results_summary: StretchView enabled long-term, automated imaging of cells in stretched and relaxed states (12 hours), demonstrating stable strain fields over 18 hours of cyclic stretching. The study observed a monotonic increase in junctional E-cadherin localization during stretching, suggesting enhanced monolayer barrier integrity.
population_specificity: MDCK cells in monolayer (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of plantar fascia stretching versus calf stretching on ankle dorsiflexion, balance, gait parameters, and disability index in chronic post-stroke patients.
results_summary: Plantar fascia stretching significantly improved ankle dorsiflexion, static balance (both open and closed eyes), cadence, and disability index compared to calf stretching after 4 weeks. All improvements were statistically significant (p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Chronic post-stroke patients (n=20, split into two groups of 10).
effective_dosage: 5 times per week for 4 weeks, 3 sets of 10 repetitions per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of stretching on spasticity, range of motion, and motor function in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) and challenge assumptions about its benefits.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence supporting stretching's short-term effects on spasticity in SCI patients, with preclinical data in rats suggesting stretching may impair motor function and reduce spinal cord excitability. Long-term effects and impacts on motor function in humans remain unexamined.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) and preclinical studies in rats with SCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 10-week static stretching program could improve ankle dorsiflexion range of motion and reduce tissue hardness in older adults.
results_summary: The 10-week stretching program significantly increased ankle dorsiflexion range of motion and decreased tissue hardness, but these changes were not correlated, suggesting ROM improvements were due to stretch tolerance rather than tissue changes.
population_specificity: 24 community-dwelling older adults (mean age 73.8 ± 5.1 years).
effective_dosage: 4 × 30-second repetitions, at least three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to translate the SARAH hand exercise program into Gujarati and assess its adherence rate, usefulness, and understanding among participants.
results_summary: The adherence rate was 97.22%, with participants reporting the booklet as understandable, useful, and beneficial for reducing symptoms and improving daily and occupational activities.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis of the hand in Gujarat, India.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program involved 72 sessions over 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute and long-term effects of stretching type, duration, and intensity on joint range of motion (ROM) and stiffness in ankle contractures.
results_summary: Constant-torque stretching acutely increased ROM more than constant-angle and dynamic stretching, with ROM improvements also linked to stretching duration. Long-term effects on ROM and stiffness showed no significant impact from stretching duration or type, though data on stretch type's long-term effects were insufficient.
population_specificity: Individuals with ankle contractures (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intensity and duration varied but were not quantified in most studies).
study_duration: Acute effects assessed immediately post-stretching; long-term effects evaluated over ≥1 week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short-term safety and efficacy of static stretching combined with daily walking in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus presenting with proliferative diabetic retinopathy and peripheral arterial disease.
results_summary: The study found no new intraocular hemorrhage or increased intraocular pressure during the intervention, and improvements were observed in blood pressure, glycemic control, and cardio-ankle vascular index. The combination of static stretching and walking appeared safe and effective for the studied population.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, proliferative diabetic retinopathy, and peripheral arterial disease of the lower extremities.
effective_dosage: 40 minutes of other-movement static stretching and in-hospital walking during a two-week hospitalization phase; 20-30 minutes of automatic static stretching and outdoor walking during a two-week home phase post-discharge; 10,000 steps/day.
study_duration: Four weeks (two weeks in-hospital, two weeks at home).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal frequency, intensity, and volume of static stretching to maximize flexibility and investigate potential moderating factors like muscle group, age, sex, training status, and baseline flexibility.
results_summary: The study found moderate positive effects of acute static stretching and large positive effects of chronic static stretching on flexibility, with improvements maximized at 4 minutes per session (acute) and 10 minutes per week (chronic). Larger improvements were observed in individuals with poor baseline flexibility and in the hamstrings compared to the spine.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years (61% male; mean age 26.8 ± 11.4 years).
effective_dosage: 4 minutes per session (acute), 10 minutes per week (chronic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of stretching versus compression exercises on the flexion-relaxation response in patients with deep gluteal syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the flexion-relaxation ratio between stretching, compression, and control groups. However, stretching exercises showed a more significant effect on reducing disability scores compared to compression exercises.
population_specificity: Patients with deep gluteal syndrome (n=45).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of physiotherapy treatment at a frequency of three per week.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied over approximately 3-4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining radiofrequency therapy with static stretching (SS) is superior to SS alone in improving hamstring flexibility.
results_summary: The study found that combining RF therapy with SS produced different changes in muscle properties compared to SS alone, particularly in lateral hamstring elasticity, but these changes did not translate to differences in knee extension range of motion.
population_specificity: 33 participants with hamstring tightness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of stretching exercises in reducing restless leg syndrome (RLS) severity and improving related outcomes in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Stretching exercises significantly reduced RLS severity and improved secondary outcomes such as sleep quality, depression, and physical performance, with comparable efficacy to dopamine agonists in symptom reduction.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients with restless leg syndrome
study_duration: Ranging from eight weeks to six months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of exercise-based rehabilitation programs on craniovertebral (CV) junction health, focusing on pain levels, joint mobility, function, and quality of life.
results_summary: The study found mixed results, with no significant differences in forward head posture improvement between corrective and conventional exercises, and modest benefits when comparing exercise treatment to physiotherapy or no treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with CV junction disorders, including those experiencing neck pain, restricted movement, and neurological issues.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of deep dry needling combined with stretching versus stretching alone for pain relief in patients with myofascial trigger points (MTPs).
results_summary: The pooled effect size for pain reduction was -1.73 (95% CI: -3.06; -0.40), suggesting that adding deep dry needling to stretching may be more effective than stretching alone. However, the risk of bias was unclear in four studies and high in one.
population_specificity: Patients with myofascial trigger points (MTPs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating neurodynamic slump stretch and suboccipital muscle inhibition into passive static stretching improves hamstring flexibility in individuals with short hamstrings.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in hamstring flexibility (measured by PAT and SLR tests) for groups receiving neurodynamic slump stretch or suboccipital muscle inhibition combined with passive static stretching, compared to passive static stretching alone. No significant differences were observed in the FBT between groups.
population_specificity: 117 female participants with short hamstrings.
effective_dosage: Three sessions per week, 10 minutes each.

study_goal: To determine the effect of respiratory muscle stretching on respiratory function and gait endurance in stroke patients.
results_summary: Respiratory muscle stretching significantly improved respiratory function and gait endurance in stroke patients, with notable increases in maximal expiratory pressure and 6-minute walk test performance.
population_specificity: Thirty stroke patients with limited chest expansion and respiratory muscle asymmetry.
effective_dosage: Respiratory muscle stretching 3 times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of stretching exercises in reducing pain intensity and improving function in patients with non-specific low back pain (LBP).
results_summary: Stretching exercises reduced pain (NRS score of 4 post-intervention) and improved function, but were less effective than strengthening exercises. The SF-12 questionnaire indicated overall health improvement in patients.
population_specificity: 90 patients with non-specific LBP who performed prolonged sedentary work.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of plantar-specific calf stretching exercises versus PRP injections for pain relief in plantar fasciitis.
results_summary: The study found that stretching exercises were equally effective as PRP injections in reducing pain, with no reported complications or recurrences in the stretching group, unlike the PRP group.
population_specificity: Indoor patients with plantar fasciitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only described as "plantar-specific calf stretching exercises").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of selective lateral hamstring strengthening and medial hamstring stretching versus general hamstring stretching and strengthening on pain, disability, and quality of life in patients with knee osteoarthritis and varus deformity.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in pain, disability, and physical activity, but the selective hamstring strengthening group exhibited greater improvements in symptoms and pain subscales. Quality of life did not significantly improve in the general hamstring strengthening group.
population_specificity: Patients with primary knee osteoarthritis and varus deformity (40 participants, predominantly women).
effective_dosage: Treatment program conducted three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of six weeks of regular stretching on regional and widespread pain sensitivity and range of motion, as well as the persistence of these effects after four weeks of cessation.
results_summary: Six weeks of stretching significantly increased regional and distant pressure pain thresholds and range of motion. These benefits persisted even after four weeks of cessation, indicating a lasting hypoalgesic effect.
population_specificity: 26 healthy adults aged 21-30 years.
effective_dosage: Daily bilateral hamstring stretching exercises (specific duration/frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Six weeks of stretching followed by four weeks of cessation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week active hamstring stretching protocol combined with core stabilization and education could reduce nonspecific low back pain and discomfort during prolonged sitting in young adults.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group showed significant reductions in pain intensity, low back discomfort, and functional disability compared to baseline and the control group. Additionally, the experimental group demonstrated improved satisfaction and hamstring flexibility.
population_specificity: 52 students aged 18-25
effective_dosage: Active hamstring stretching protocol (specific details not provided)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of Global Active Stretching on muscle strength and flexibility in individuals with short hamstrings.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant increases in flexibility (8.3 cm in the fingertip-to-floor test and 6.3° in the active knee extension test) compared to placebo and control groups, with no significant changes in muscle strength.
population_specificity: 30 volunteers with more than 20° in the active knee extension test (indicating short hamstrings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the combined effects of dry needling and static stretching on spasticity, motor neuron excitability, function, and quality of life in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study will compare the effects of dry needling plus static stretching versus sham dry needling plus static stretching, with outcomes measured at baseline, post-treatment, and follow-up. Results are pending, but the study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness of this combined approach.
population_specificity: Patients with post-stroke spasticity in the plantar flexor muscles.
effective_dosage: Static stretching (20 min × 5 days/week); dry needling (60s × 3 days/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of an automatic wound closure system using different traction forces to stretch dermal-collagen fibers and achieve primary wound closure while reducing scar hyperplasia.
results_summary: The study found that a traction force of 30 N effectively achieved primary wound closure and reduced scar hyperplasia, while 60 N caused collagen-fiber breakdown. The automatic system outperformed manual suturing in terms of wound closure and scar reduction.
population_specificity: Bama miniature pigs with full-thickness wounds (8 × 14 cm).
effective_dosage: Traction forces of 15 N, 30 N, and 60 N.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the auricular growth potential of patients with concha-type microtia at different ages after auricular cartilage stretching surgery.
results_summary: The study found that surgical intervention improved auricular aesthetics and released growth potential, with faster growth observed before 3 years of age. Grade II patients showed growth potential consistent with normal auricles, while Grade III patients had significantly different growth outcomes.
population_specificity: 66 patients with unilateral grade II and III concha-type microtia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how peripheral and central nociceptive mechanisms contribute to muscle stretch-induced locomotor deficits following spinal cord injury.
results_summary: Hindlimb muscle stretching caused significant deficits in locomotor recovery after spinal cord injury. Baclofen and Ibuprofen partially mitigated stretching effects on hindlimb responses like spasticity and writhing but did not prevent locomotor function decline. Morphine worsened clonic-like vibrations during stretching.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats with moderate T10 contusion spinal cord injuries.
effective_dosage: Daily hindlimb muscle stretching during weeks 4, 5, 9, and 10 post-injury; drugs administered with stretching during weeks 4 and 9 only.
interactions: Morphine exacerbated clonic-like vibrations; Baclofen and Ibuprofen reduced spasticity and writhing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of stretching exercises on fibromyalgia symptoms and assess the quality of existing evidence.
results_summary: Stretching exercises may improve pain, health-related quality of life, and physical and mental functioning in fibromyalgia patients, but the evidence is of low quality due to intervention heterogeneity and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of hamstring stretching exercises in relieving pain intensity and improving function in patients with low back pain.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that hamstring stretching significantly reduced pain scores and improved function, particularly in cases of back pain with radiating pain, as evidenced by increased range of motion and lower Oswestry Disability Index scores.
population_specificity: Patients with low back pain (n=735 participants across 14 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of ballistic stretching (BS) and voluntary isometric contraction at maximal shortening (VICAMS) on range of motion, strength, and vertical jump performance.
results_summary: VICAMS showed statistically significant improvements in active range of motion (AROM), maximal voluntary isometric force (MVIF), and countermovement jump height (CMJ) compared to BS and the control group. Both VICAMS and BS groups demonstrated intra-group improvements from baseline across all measured variables.
population_specificity: 60 healthy, physically active individuals aged 40-52 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intraoral splints providing graded, low-load, multidirectional stretch for improving microstomia and orofacial contractures in facial burn survivors.
results_summary: The study observed both positive (tissue lengthening) and negative (tissue shortening) changes in facial landmarks, with participants reporting functional improvements in oral motor and psychosocial function posttreatment. However, the small sample size limits generalizability.
population_specificity: Facial burn survivors, including those with mature scars.
study_duration: Not specified (weekly measurements over an unspecified trial period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a regular stretching program could reduce functional consequences of pain for healthcare professionals working in echocardiographic, ultrasound, and interventional laboratories.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in upper extremity disability and neck disability scores, but no significant change in low back disability. No stretch-related injuries were reported.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals (72% female, 72% over 40 years) working in interventional and echocardiographic laboratories.
effective_dosage: 15-minute neck, upper extremity, low back, and lower extremity stretches (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of L-tryptophan metabolism in lower limb ischemia and thrombosis.
results_summary: The study identified L-tryptophan as a key metabolite linked to lower limb ischemia and thrombosis, with B0AT1 (encoded by SLC6A19) playing a crucial role in its metabolism. These findings suggest a potential pathway for understanding and treating the condition.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb ischemia (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic effects and mechanisms of TUDCA in STZ-induced type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced blood glucose, HbA1c%, and HOMA-IR while increasing insulin levels. It also improved lipid profiles, reduced inflammation, enhanced antioxidant defenses, and decreased apoptotic markers in the pancreas.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar albino male rats with STZ-induced type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of tryptophan (TRP) restriction on gastrointestinal symptoms, quality of life, and psychological well-being in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: Low-TRP intake reduced gastrointestinal discomfort and improved psychological well-being in IBS patients, while acute TRP depletion yielded mixed results. Safety data from one trial reported no adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (135 participants across five trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate TUDCA's potential therapeutic effects in mitigating ER stress induced by tunicamycin in Pak choi plants.
results_summary: TUDCA improved plant morphology, reduced ROS accumulation, restored cellular membrane integrity, and enhanced the antioxidant defense system. It also modulated ER stress-related gene expression, alleviated oxidative stress, and positively influenced plant growth.
population_specificity: Pak choi (Brassica campestris subsp. chinensis) plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Tryptophan Metabolism-associated Genes (ECHS1 and ALDH2) in gastric cancer progression, immune modulation, and their potential as immunotherapy targets.
results_summary: The study found that ECHS1 down-regulation and ALDH2 up-regulation reduced tumor microenvironment heterogeneity, inflammation, and inhibited tumor cell migration and proliferation. These genes also modulated CD8+ and CD4+ T cell activities, impacting gastric cancer progression.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer (GC) cell lines (AGS and SNU-1) and tumor microenvironment analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether long-term TUDCA administration alters gut microbiota (GM) in a human patient and the impact of antibiotic therapy on microbial diversity.
results_summary: The study found a dominant shift toward Firmicutes and remodeling in Proteobacteria abundance in the patient's gut microbiota, contrary to the expected prevalence of Bacteroidetes. This suggests TUDCA may influence GM composition.
population_specificity: A 92-year-old woman with Alzheimer's disease and home enteral nutrition, prescribed TUDCA for lithiasis cholangitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could mitigate ER stress and improve mitochondrial bioenergetics in SEPN1-related myopathy (SEPN1-RM) by targeting ERO1A overexpression.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment in SEPN1 knockout mice mirrored the beneficial effects of ERO1A loss, reducing ER stress and improving mitochondrial function. Additionally, TUDCA-treated SEPN1-RM patient-derived myoblasts showed improved bioenergetics, suggesting therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: SEPN1 knockout mice and SEPN1-RM patient-derived primary myoblasts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of oral TUDCA in reducing ER stress and improving clinical disease activity in patients with active ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: TUDCA was well-tolerated, reduced ER stress and inflammation, and significantly improved clinical, endoscopic, and histologic disease activity. The mean total Mayo Score decreased from 9 to 4.5 after 6 weeks of treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate-to-severely active ulcerative colitis (Mayo score ≥6, endoscopic subscore ≥1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA has disease-modifying activity in ALS patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing and aims to compare disease progression during TUDCA treatment versus placebo, with potential biomarker validation. No specific results are reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 320 ALS patients across 25 centers in seven European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the neuroprotective effects and mechanisms of TUDCA in retinal disorders.
results_summary: TUDCA effectively delayed retinal neuron degeneration and apoptosis, preserved retinal structure and function, and acted through mechanisms like inhibiting apoptosis, reducing inflammation, and attenuating oxidative stress. The review reinforced TUDCA's potential as a therapeutic agent for retinal diseases.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo models of retinal disorders (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa, diabetic retinopathy, retinal degeneration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of TUDCA as an add-on therapy to riluzole in slowing disease progression in ALS patients.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, with primary outcomes focused on a 20% improvement in the ALSFRS-R slope over 18 months. Results will determine if TUDCA effectively slows ALS progression.
population_specificity: Patients with ALS receiving riluzole.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of TUDCA on adipose tissue dysfunction and metabolic alterations in obesity, focusing on its potential as a therapeutic strategy.
results_summary: TUDCA was found to limit metabolic disturbances in obesity by inhibiting ER stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in adipocytes, and it may improve perivascular adipose tissue function and adiponectin release, suggesting cardiovascular benefits.
population_specificity: Obesity-related metabolic disorders (animal or human study not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA alleviates placental endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and improves fetal growth in a rat model of advanced maternal age, with sex-specific effects.
results_summary: TUDCA reduced ER stress markers (GRP78, phospho-eIF2α, ATF-4, CHOP) in the placental labyrinth zone of male offspring from aged dams and improved fetal growth in both sexes, but effects were sex-specific and varied by placental zone.
population_specificity: Aged pregnant rats (≥35 years equivalent) and their male and female offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could mitigate ER stress-related vascular dysfunction and improve pregnancy outcomes in aged dams.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment reduced ER stress markers (phospho-eIF2α and CHOP), lowered blood pressure, improved fetal weight, and tended to enhance uterine artery function in aged dams compared to controls.
population_specificity: Aged pregnant rats (term = 22 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether TUDCA could suppress endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress, oxidative stress, and apoptosis in a PTZ-induced epilepsy model in rats.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment significantly reduced markers of ER stress (ATF4, ATF6), oxidative stress (NOX2, MDA), and apoptosis (Cleaved-Caspase3, Caspase12), while also preserving neuronal integrity in the hippocampus. The results suggest TUDCA may mitigate ER stress-related damage in epileptic seizures.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats (n=48) with PTZ-induced seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could mitigate inflammation, oxidative stress, and tissue damage caused by seizures in brain stem, heart, and lung tissues.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced expression of inflammatory and hypoxic markers (NF-κB p65, TNF-α, Kir6.2, HIF1α) in most tissues and improved histopathological changes, though it only partially reduced apoptosis.
population_specificity: Wistar Albino male rats (250-300 g, n=32)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA improves pancreatic β-cell function in obesity by regulating mitochondrial metabolism and insulin secretion under fatty acid exposure.
results_summary: TUDCA normalized insulin secretion in INS1-E cells exposed to fatty acids, reduced mitochondrial stress markers (citrate synthase, mitochondrial mass, membrane potential), and decreased mitochondrial superoxide and JNK protein content, suggesting improved mitochondrial metabolism and redox balance.
population_specificity: Insulin-producing cells (INS1-E) exposed to fatty acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate TUDCA's effects on body weight, adiposity, and hypothalamic appetite control in a streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: TUDCA reduced food intake, increased energy expenditure, improved hypothalamic leptin signaling, and normalized inflammatory markers and neuropeptide expression in the Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease mouse model (Stz mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA protects rat dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons from tunicamycin-induced apoptosis by suppressing endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced apoptosis and oxidative stress markers in DRG neurons exposed to tunicamycin, while also downregulating ER stress-related proteins. The study suggests TUDCA may protect neurons by inhibiting ER stress activation.
population_specificity: Primary cultured rat dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore TUDCA's neuroprotective mechanisms and pathways in neurodegenerative disorders, extending existing knowledge on its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: TUDCA demonstrated neuroprotective effects in models of Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and Huntington's diseases by inhibiting apoptosis, reducing oxidative stress, and mitigating endoplasmic reticulum stress. The study highlights its potential as a novel treatment for these conditions.
population_specificity: Experimental models of neurodegenerative disorders (not specified if human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could protect against dopaminergic neuronal damage, neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and autophagy in a progressive model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: TUDCA pretreatment protected against dopaminergic neuronal damage, prevented neuroinflammation, reduced oxidative stress, inhibited autophagy, and prevented alpha-synuclein aggregation, though it did not significantly affect locomotion.
population_specificity: Mice in a progressive Parkinson's disease model (MPTP + Probenecid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential chondroprotective effects of TUDCA on IL-1β- and TNC-stimulated NHAC-kn chondrocytes under normoxic and hypoxic conditions.
results_summary: TUDCA alleviated ER stress and reduced inflammatory markers in IL-1β-stimulated cells but did not prevent apoptosis in either normoxia or hypoxia. It also enhanced Col IIα expression in normoxic conditions.
population_specificity: NHAC-kn chondrocytes (a human chondrocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and optimize a multi-loaded PLGA-microsphere system incorporating TUDCA and GDNF for sustained intraocular drug delivery to treat retinitis pigmentosa.
results_summary: The study demonstrated improved encapsulation efficiency (78.58±10.40%) and sustained in vitro release of TUDCA over 91 days when using optimized formulation parameters, suggesting potential for prolonged therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on encapsulation efficiency and release profiles).
study_duration: In vitro release monitored for 91 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of TUDCA on glucose metabolism and cognitive function in a streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease mice model.
results_summary: TUDCA improved glucose tolerance, insulin sensitivity, reduced glycemia, increased islet mass and β-cell area, enhanced glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, reduced neuroinflammation, decreased amyloid oligomer content in the hippocampus, improved memory, and increased insulin receptor β-subunit protein content.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease mice model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA reduces ER stress and apoptosis while improving developmental competence in ICSI embryos, both in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced ER stress and apoptosis in ICSI embryos, comparable to IVF embryos, and improved developmental outcomes, including pregnancy, implantation, and birth rates.
population_specificity: ICSI embryos (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate TUDCA's potential in treating neonatal necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) and its mechanisms of action in vivo and in vitro.
results_summary: TUDCA reduced mortality, prolonged survival, diminished intestinal damage, and inhibited inflammation in NEC mice. It achieved these effects by suppressing endoplasmic reticulum stress markers, inhibiting intestinal cell apoptosis, and activating the Akt pathway.
population_specificity: Neonatal mice with induced necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current experimental and clinical data on hydrophilic bile acids, including TUDCA, and their role in treating certain liver diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that hydrophilic bile acids like TUDCA have been revamped as therapeutic approaches for liver diseases, particularly in addressing cholestasis and hepatocyte adaptive responses to injury. It suggests these BAs help delineate the pathophysiology of liver injury and may offer clinical benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with liver diseases, particularly those involving cholestasis or hepatocyte injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA improves glycemic control in mice with early-stage type 1 diabetes (T1D).
results_summary: TUDCA treatment reduced blood glucose by 43% in diabetic mice, likely due to increased insulinemia, reduced hepatic IDE activity, and higher beta-cell mass. No changes in insulin sensitivity were observed.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with streptozotocin-induced early-stage T1D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could enhance mitochondrial function in CKD-derived hMSCs and improve therapeutic outcomes in a murine model of CKD and hindlimb ischemia.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment improved mitochondrial function in CKD-hMSCs via the PINK1-PrPC pathway and enhanced functional recovery (kidney function, limb salvage, blood perfusion, and vessel formation) in mice with CKD and hindlimb ischemia.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and a murine hindlimb ischemia model with CKD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could restore osteoarthritis (OA) cartilage by reducing cholesterol levels in OA chondrocytes and stimulating chondrogenic signaling.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment significantly increased cell proliferation, chondrogenic marker expression (SOX9, COL2, ACAN), and glycosaminoglycan production while reducing intracellular cholesterol and improving membrane fluidity. It also enhanced TGF receptor 1 stability and focal adhesion protein activity.
population_specificity: Degenerated chondrocytes isolated from patients with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA is reno-protective in a model of ETB receptor deficiency with chronic high salt-induced renal injury and inflammation.
results_summary: TUDCA prevented high salt diet-induced glomerular and tubular damage in ETB-deficient rats, reduced kidney injury markers, decreased glomerular permeability, restored proximal tubule brush borders, and reduced renal inflammation, though it had no significant effect on blood pressure.
population_specificity: ETB-deficient and transgenic control rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA-treated mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) could protect neural cells from CKD-mediated endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: TUDCA-treated CKD-hMSCs increased antioxidant enzyme activities in SH-SY5Y cells by upregulating cellular prion protein (PrPC) expression, protecting against ER stress and apoptosis. In a murine CKD model, TUDCA-treated CKD-hMSCs suppressed ROS generation and ER stress in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Murine CKD model and human MSCs isolated from CKD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could improve insulin clearance in obesity-induced hyperinsulinemia by enhancing liver IDE expression via the S1PR2-Insulin pathway.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment restored plasma insulin to physiological levels in HFD mice by increasing insulin clearance and liver IDE expression. This effect was dependent on S1PR2-Insulin pathway activation, as inhibition of S1PR2 or downstream proteins blocked IDE expression.
population_specificity: High-fat diet (HFD) mice and human hepatic cell line HepG2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could alleviate rifampicin-induced liver injury in HepG2 cells by enhancing bile acid transporter expression and the Nrf2-mediated adaptive response.
results_summary: TUDCA increased bile acid transporter and Nrf2 expression, reduced oxidative stress markers, decreased apoptosis, and improved cell survival while lowering liver injury biomarkers in HepG2 cells exposed to rifampicin.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for converting chicken bile-derived TCDCA into TUDCA using immobilized enzymes, improving the utilization of chicken bile waste.
results_summary: The study achieved a TUDCA yield of approximately 62% after equilibrium, with TUDCA content in the reaction product reaching 33.16%. Enzyme activity was significantly inhibited by bilirubin, Cu2+, and Ca2+ in the complex substrate.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro enzymatic catalysis study).
interactions: Inhibited by bilirubin, Cu2+, and Ca2+.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of TUDCA on microglial cells and its potential as a therapeutic target for neuroinflammation-related pathologies.
results_summary: TUDCA binding to GPBAR1/TGR5 increased intracellular cAMP levels in microglia, promoting anti-inflammatory markers and reducing pro-inflammatory ones. The anti-inflammatory effect was confirmed in both in vitro and in vivo models of acute neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: Microglial cells (central nervous system resident macrophages) and a mouse model of acute neuroinflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could reduce endoplasmic reticulum stress (ERS) and attenuate pressure overload-induced cardiac remodeling in a mouse model of transverse aortic constriction (TAC).
results_summary: TUDCA administration reduced ERS markers, cardiac hypertrophy, myocardial fibrosis, collagen deposition, and apoptosis, while normalizing gene expression related to extracellular matrix and mitochondrial function in the TAC model.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to transverse aortic constriction (TAC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of TUDCA and PBA in mitigating stress-induced protein aggregation and their impact on cellular pathways related to apoptosis and ER stress.
results_summary: TUDCA was more effective than PBA in mitigating BSA protein aggregation and enhancing trypsin-mediated digestion. It activated the PERK-eIF2α-ATF4 pathway without reducing cell viability, unlike PBA, and protected against various stressors (tunicamycin, UV-irradiation, PBA). Neither chaperone promoted BiP or CHOP expression.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells (a human liver cancer cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could reverse autophagy impairment caused by TTR V30M aggregates and serve as a therapeutic approach for TTR V30M-related amyloidosis.
results_summary: TUDCA effectively reversed p62 accumulation in the GI tract of TTR V30M transgenic animals, indicating its ability to modulate autophagy and mitigate apoptosis. The study suggests TUDCA as a potential therapeutic for TTR V30M-related amyloidosis.
population_specificity: TTR V30M transgenic mice and cell culture models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of TUDCA compared to UDCA for treating primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) in Chinese patients.
results_summary: TUDCA was found to be as efficacious as UDCA in reducing serum ALP levels, with 75.97% of TUDCA-treated patients achieving a >25% reduction. TUDCA also showed a better safety profile regarding pruritus/scratch symptoms compared to UDCA.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with primary biliary cholangitis (PBC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how TUDCA improves insulin resistance in obese mice by examining its effects on autophagic dysfunction and endoplasmic reticulum stress.
