results_summary: TUDCA injections reduced body weight gain, lowered blood glucose, improved insulin sensitivity, reversed autophagic dysfunction and ER stress, and restored impaired insulin signaling in obese mice. Similar effects were observed with adenoviral Atg7 treatment.
population_specificity: Obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA enhances retinal phagocytosis and protects against hydrogen peroxide-induced phagocytic dysfunction in RPE cells.
results_summary: TUDCA enhanced phagocytosis of photoreceptor outer segments (POS) and protected against H2O2-induced dysfunction by activating MerTK, a key receptor in POS renewal. The results suggest TUDCA could be a therapeutic option for retinal diseases.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 cell line and primary human RPE cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could preserve cone cells in Lrat(-/-) mice by reducing ER stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: TUDCA treatment significantly reduced ER stress and apoptosis, slowed cone degeneration, and increased cone density by ∼3-fold in Lrat(-/-) mice. It also enhanced the degradation of cone membrane-associated proteins via the ER-associated protein degradation pathway.
population_specificity: Lrat(-/-) mice (a model for Leber congenital amaurosis).
effective_dosage: Systemic administration every 3 days (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether systemic administration of TUDCA could protect photoreceptors from cell death after experimental retinal detachment in rodents.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced photoreceptor cell death, preserved outer nuclear layer thickness, and decreased oxidative stress and caspase activity, but did not affect macrophage recruitment or cytokine levels.
population_specificity: Rodents (rats) with experimentally induced retinal detachment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could reduce amyloid-β accumulation and improve cognitive deficits in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: TUDCA reduced Aβ deposits, improved memory deficits, decreased glial activation, and preserved neuronal integrity in APP/PS1 mice. It also modulated lipid metabolism mediators linked to Aβ production, suggesting a potential mechanism for its effects.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 double-transgenic mice (a model for Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could prevent neointimal hyperplasia by suppressing the growth and migration of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs).
results_summary: TUDCA reduced VSMC viability and migration by inhibiting ERK via PKCα-mediated MKP-1 induction and suppressed MMP-9 expression. In rats with carotid artery balloon injury, TUDCA significantly decreased neointimal hyperplasia by reducing VSMC proliferation and inducing apoptosis.
population_specificity: Human vascular smooth muscle cells (hVSMCs) and rats with carotid artery balloon injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the protective effects of TUDCA on photoreceptor degeneration in different mouse models of retinal degeneration.
results_summary: TUDCA preserved ERG b-waves and retinal structure in Bbs1(M390R/M390R) and rd10 mice but showed no improvement in rd1 and rd16 mice. It also reduced obesity in Bbs1(M390R/M390R) mice.
population_specificity: Mice with retinal degeneration (Bbs1(M390R/M390R), rd10, rd1, and rd16 models).
effective_dosage: Subcutaneous injections twice a week (Bbs1), every 3 days (rd10), and daily (rd1 and rd16).
study_duration: Varied by model: P40-P120 (Bbs1), P6-P38 (rd10), P6-P30 (rd1 and rd16).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of TUDCA, alone and in combination with doxycycline, in reducing TTR deposition and associated markers in transgenic TTR mice models of Familial Amyloidotic Polyneuropathy (FAP).
results_summary: TUDCA was effective at lowering non-fibrillar TTR deposition and pre-fibrillar markers in young mice. Combined cycled administration with doxycycline showed synergistic effects, significantly reducing TTR deposition and tissue markers more effectively than either drug alone.
population_specificity: Transgenic TTR-V30M mice modeling Familial Amyloidotic Polyneuropathy (FAP).
effective_dosage: Not specified for TUDCA alone; combined with doxycycline at two different concentrations.
study_duration: Not specified for TUDCA alone; intermittent treatments with doxycycline included 15-day cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could inhibit ER stress induced by thapsigargin and restore glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in pig islets.
results_summary: TUDCA restored insulin secretion reduced by thapsigargin, decreased islet regression rates, enhanced ATP content, and improved glucose-stimulated insulin secretion in pig islets.
population_specificity: Pig islets

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TUDCA could reduce apoptosis and improve cardiac function in rats following myocardial infarction.
results_summary: TUDCA significantly reduced apoptotic cells and caspase-3 activity in rats after ischemic injury, and by 4 weeks, it resulted in a smaller infarct area and improved heart function compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Rats with induced myocardial infarction
study_duration: 24 hours for apoptosis assessment, 4 weeks for functional outcomes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of TUDCA on hepatocyte proliferation in patients with HCV-correlated chronic liver disease.
results_summary: TUDCA reduced ALT levels and Knodell's score while significantly increasing PCNA-LI, suggesting it may stimulate hepatocyte proliferation in humans.
population_specificity: 5 patients with HCV-correlated chronic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining TUDCA with interferon improves treatment outcomes for chronic hepatitis C compared to interferon alone.
results_summary: The study found similar rates of normalized ALT levels and negative viremia between the two regimens, but TUDCA allowed a lower cumulative interferon dose to maintain normal ALT levels during the tapering phase. Liver histology improvements were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: 106 patients with chronic hepatitis C
study_duration: 6 months of full treatment followed by 6 months of interferon tapering

study_goal: To determine whether TUDCA prevents or ameliorates liver injury in neonates treated with total parenteral nutrition (TPN).
results_summary: TUDCA showed no significant difference in preventing or treating TPN-associated cholestasis in neonates, with similar peak serum CB, ALT, AP, and BA levels between treated and control groups. The study concluded that TUDCA appears ineffective for this purpose.
population_specificity: Neonates (infants) undergoing surgery and receiving TPN, stratified by birth weight (<1500 g and >1500 g).
study_duration: Blood chemistries were monitored weekly, with comparisons made after 14, 40, 60, 70, and 120 days of TPN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how TUDCA administration affects biliary lipid composition and cholesterol saturation in patients with radiolucent gallstones.
results_summary: TUDCA administration led to a dose-dependent decrease in cholesterol saturation, an increase in ursodeoxycholate percentage in bile, and a higher fraction of taurine-conjugated ursodeoxycholate. At 11 mg/kg/day, cholesterol saturation dropped to 80%, with ursodeoxycholic acid constituting 45% of biliary bile acids.
population_specificity: 33 patients with radiolucent gallstones.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the activity and safety of TUDCA (500 mg/day) in preventing dyspepsia in cholecystectomized patients compared to an untreated control group.
results_summary: TUDCA showed a prompt regression in dyspepsia symptom severity at the one-month follow-up compared to the untreated group, but no significant differences were observed at two and three months. Adverse events were minimal (2 in TUDCA group, 3 in control group).
population_specificity: Cholecystectomized patients (203 total, 101 in TUDCA group, 102 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety, tolerability, and biological effects of TUDCA supplementation in people with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS) and explore its potential link to brain and retinal atrophy.
results_summary: Higher baseline bile acid levels predicted slower brain and retinal atrophy in MS. TUDCA supplementation was safe and tolerable, increased serum bile acids, but showed no significant differences in clinical or biomarker outcomes.
population_specificity: People with progressive multiple sclerosis (PMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial efficacy of an ethanolic extract of Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum) against Tannerella forsythia, a key periodontal pathogen, compared to chlorhexidine.
results_summary: The ethanolic extract of Tulsi demonstrated statistically significant antibacterial activity against T. forsythia, with inhibition zones of 17 mm at 25 mg/mL and 25 mm at 50 mg/mL, though slightly less effective than 0.2% chlorhexidine (32 mm). The highest efficacy was observed at the 50 mg/mL concentration.
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial culture (Tannerella forsythia).
effective_dosage: 3.13%, 6.25%, 12.5%, 25%, and 50% concentrations (25 mg/mL and 50 mg/mL noted for efficacy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the adaptogenic properties of tulsi leaf extract on in vitro regeneration of tobacco leaf explants and its role in modulating plant morphogenesis.
results_summary: Tulsi extract (20%) nearly doubled the number of regenerants after four weeks, reduced browning, and led to accumulation of stress-related indoleamines like tryptamine and N-acetyl-serotonin. It also demonstrated melatonin and 2-hydroxymelatonin as key antioxidants during stress adaptation.
population_specificity: In vitro tobacco leaf explants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of tulsi extract with curcumin as a locally administered medication (LAM) for treating periodontal pockets.
results_summary: Tulsi extract was found to be more effective than curcumin in eradicating red-complex bacteria (based on BAPNA assay results), while curcumin showed a greater reduction in plaque and gingival inflammation. Both treatments had similar overall effectiveness in reducing periodontal markers.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal pockets (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate the properties of magnesium oxide (MgO) nanoparticles synthesized using tulsi seed extract, focusing on their potential for water purification and pollution control.
results_summary: The study found that the MgCN nanocomposite with 1.5 mM MgO exhibited enhanced morphology, high surface area, improved visible light absorption, and significant adsorption and photocatalytic degradation capabilities, achieving up to 98% removal of methylene blue and 54% removal of tetracycline antibiotics, along with antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 0.5 mM, 1.0 mM, 1.5 mM, and 2.0 mM MgO concentrations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of gold nanoparticles synthesized using a dual extract of tulsi and Vinca (T+V-Gold) in a triple-negative breast cancer murine model.
results_summary: The T+V-Gold nanoparticles delayed tumor development, reduced tumor burden, and showed significant antitumor effects by modulating glutathione-related antioxidants in tumor tissues.
population_specificity: 4T1-induced triple-negative breast cancer murine model (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel herbal paste containing tulsi, turmeric, and honey in managing oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in mouth opening, tongue protrusion, burning sensation, blanching of the mucous membrane, and reduction in palpable fibrous bands in OSMF patients using the herbal paste compared to controls.
population_specificity: 80 OSMF patients (77 males, 3 females) with a predominant habit of gutka chewing, average age 28.09±8.38 years.
effective_dosage: 10 g turmeric powder + 10 g tulsi powder mixed in 10 ml honey (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties of Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum) as a potential therapeutic option for ischemic brain injury and stroke.
results_summary: The study suggests that Tulsi possesses immunomodulatory properties that may alter cellular and humoral immune responses, along with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, potentially benefiting stroke patients by mitigating ongoing immune reactions post-injury.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of stroke patients and potential therapeutic applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial efficacy of Tulsi extract against Enterococcus faecalis, Fusobacterium nucleatum, and Staphylococci epidermidis in root canal disinfection.
results_summary: Tulsi extract showed antimicrobial activity but was less effective than chlorhexidine and sodium hypochlorite, with higher minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) compared to these conventional agents.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (E. faecalis, F. nucleatum, S. epidermidis) in a laboratory setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Tulsi as a local drug delivery agent in improving periodontal parameters compared to scaling and root planing alone or with curcumin.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi gel significantly improved periodontal parameters, including a statistically significant reduction in the BAPNA assay compared to scaling and root planing alone. Both Tulsi and curcumin showed effectiveness, suggesting potential as alternative local drug delivery agents.
population_specificity: 15 patients with periodontal disease (split-mouth design).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of tulsi extract mouthrinse against chlorhexidine and hydrogen peroxide mouthrinses in reducing halitosis, plaque, and gingivitis.
results_summary: Tulsi was effective in reducing halitosis, plaque, and gingivitis, though less so than chlorhexidine and hydrogen peroxide. It was noted for its lack of side effects and cost-effectiveness.
population_specificity: 45 participants aged 17-35 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Ocimum sanctum (Tulsi) gel with Chlorhexidine (CHX) gel in treating gingivitis.
results_summary: Tulsi gel showed significant improvement in plaque index (PI) and clinical attachment loss (CAL) compared to baseline, with p<0.05, while CHX did not show significant changes in these parameters. Tulsi was effective in reducing gingival bleeding and inflammation, demonstrating promise for gingivitis treatment.
population_specificity: 30 subjects with gingivitis, divided into two groups of 15 each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review human studies on Tulsi's clinical efficacy and safety, focusing on its therapeutic effects for various conditions.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi demonstrated favorable clinical outcomes for metabolic disorders, cardiovascular disease, immunity, and neurocognition, with no significant adverse events reported. It supports traditional uses and suggests effectiveness for lifestyle-related chronic diseases.
population_specificity: Human subjects across various studies (specific populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antimicrobial activity of Ocimum sanctum (tulsi) extract against Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans and Porphyromonas gingivalis.
results_summary: The 8% concentration of tulsi extract showed the highest antimicrobial activity against both bacteria, with inhibition zones comparable to 0.2% chlorhexidine (positive control). The results were statistically significant, suggesting tulsi may be useful as an adjunctive therapy for periodontal diseases.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial cultures of A. actinomycetemcomitans and P. gingivalis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Ocimum sanctum (Tulsi) on metabolic and biochemical parameters in overweight/obese subjects.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in serum triglycerides, LDL, HDL, VLDL, BMI, plasma insulin, and insulin resistance in the Tulsi intervention group compared to the control group, with no significant changes in liver enzymes.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese subjects (n=30, divided into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: 250 mg capsule of Tulsi extract twice daily on an empty stomach.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the in vitro antimicrobial activity of Tulsi leaves extract against periodontal pathogens, comparing it to doxycycline.
results_summary: Tulsi extract at 5% and 10% concentrations showed antimicrobial activity against Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, comparable to doxycycline, but was less effective against Prevotella intermedia and Porphyromonas gingivalis.
population_specificity: In vitro study (bacterial cultures of periodontal pathogens).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical efficacy of a combination of Tulsi and turmeric for treating oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in burning sensation and mouth opening in OSMF patients treated with Tulsi and turmeric. No systemic changes were reported, indicating the combination was safe and effective for symptomatic treatment.
population_specificity: 41 patients aged 17-56 years with OSMF and no systemic complications.
effective_dosage: 1 gm Tulsi and 1 gm turmeric mixed in glycerine base, applied 3-4 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Ocimum sanctum (Tulsi) has antimicrobial activity against Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans in dental plaque and compare its effectiveness to chlorhexidine.
results_summary: Tulsi extract showed antimicrobial activity against Actinobacillus actinomycetemcomitans, with the highest effect at 6% concentration (22 mm zone of inhibition), though slightly less than chlorhexidine (25 mm). No activity was observed with the negative control.
population_specificity: 5 subjects diagnosed with periodontal disease.
effective_dosage: 1% to 10% concentrations of ethanolic Tulsi extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial activity of tulsi extract against Enterococcus faecalis in endodontic treatment, relative to chlorhexidine and neem extract.
results_summary: Tulsi extract demonstrated significant antibacterial effects against E. faecalis, though less potent than chlorhexidine but comparable to neem extract. The study concluded that herbal medicines, including tulsi, were effective alternatives to chlorhexidine for root canal disinfection.
population_specificity: In vitro samples (agar diffusion method) with E. faecalis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (extract used, no concentration or frequency detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (single-time assessment via agar diffusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the synthesis of cobalt nanoparticles using Tulsi and evaluate their potential applications in wastewater treatment and biomedical fields, specifically anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer properties.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi-mediated cobalt nanoparticles effectively removed methyl orange dye from wastewater under optimal conditions (5h incubation, pH 2, 70°C, 125μg/mL dosage). The nanoparticles also demonstrated anti-inflammatory effects at 250μg/mL and showed potential anti-cancer activity against MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells.
population_specificity: In vitro (MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells) and synthetic wastewater samples.
effective_dosage: 125μg/mL for dye removal, 250μg/mL for anti-inflammatory effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of "Ayush Tulsi Jiwan Plus" oil in managing chronic musculoskeletal pain.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain, tenderness, and swelling after 6 weeks of topical application, with no reported adverse drug reactions. Clinical improvement was observed in participants.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with mild to moderate chronic musculoskeletal pain of unknown origin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory effects of ethanolic extract of Tulsi leaves on healthy volunteers by measuring changes in cytokine levels and immune cell populations.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant increases in IFN-γ, IL-4, T-helper cells, and NK-cells after 4 weeks of Tulsi extract intervention compared to placebo. These results suggest Tulsi has immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: 24 healthy volunteers (22 completed the study)
effective_dosage: 300 mg capsules of ethanolic extract of Tulsi leaves, administered on an empty stomach

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Ocimum sanctum L. (Tulsi) in modern medicine by studying its pharmacological effects on various bodily systems.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi exhibits broad therapeutic properties, including antimicrobial, antidiabetic, cardioprotective, and anti-inflammatory effects, largely attributed to its active constituent eugenol. Pharmacological studies supported its traditional uses for managing various ailments.
population_specificity: Not specified (general reference to traditional use and pharmacological studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (mentions extracts like steam-distilled, petroleum ether, and benzene extracts but no specific dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic and therapeutic potential of Trametes versicolor (Turkey tail mushroom) extracts against human melanoma cell lines.
results_summary: The study found that Turkey tail mushroom extracts exhibited potent cytotoxic activity against melanoma cell lines (A375 and SK-MEL-5), induced apoptotic cell death, upregulated autophagy markers, and inhibited cell migration, suggesting therapeutic potential for melanoma treatment.
population_specificity: Human melanoma cell lines (A375 and SK-MEL-5) in vitro.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: fruiting body extract (663.3 µg/mL for A375, 358.4 µg/mL for SK-MEL-5); mycelium extract (114.5 µg/mL for A375, 88.6 µg/mL for SK-MEL-5).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Artneo (containing undenatured chicken collagen type II) in patients with stage III knee osteoarthritis compared to placebo.
results_summary: Artneo significantly outperformed placebo in reducing pain and stiffness, improving joint function and quality of life, and demonstrated a good safety profile.
population_specificity: 50 patients (44-75 years old) with radiological stage III knee osteoarthritis from 12 centers in the Russian Federation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Tulsi's chemopreventive and radioprotective properties, focusing on its potential in cancer prevention and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi exhibits anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antidiabetic, and immunomodulatory effects, along with chemopreventive and radioprotective properties. It also demonstrated potential in preventing chemical-induced cancers and protecting against radiation-induced DNA damage.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (mice) and in vitro models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically examine the chemopreventive and therapeutic potential of Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum) for oncologic diseases, including its biochemical and molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that Tulsi exhibits significant chemopreventive and therapeutic potential against cancer, supported by its diverse phytoconstituents and antineoplastic effects. The review highlights the biochemical and molecular mechanisms underlying these effects but notes gaps in exclusive clinical discussion for cancer prevention or therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antigenotoxic and anticlastogenic effects of Tulsi leaf extract distillate (DTLE) against genotoxicants like mitomycin C, hexavalent chromium, and benzo[a]pyrene.
results_summary: DTLE significantly protected against DNA strand breaks, chromosomal aberrations, and micronucleus formation induced by genotoxicants, with effects observed at doses of 50, 100, and 200 µL/mL. The protective effects were attributed to antioxidants like eugenol, luteolin, and apigenin.
population_specificity: Human polymorphonuclear leukocytes and peripheral lymphocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand Spondyloepiphyseal Dysplasia Congenita (SEDC) caused by COL2A1 mutations and evaluate the safety and efficacy of growth hormone (GH) therapy in SEDC patients.
results_summary: Genetic screening identified six missense mutations and one intron variant in COL2A1. GH therapy resulted in modest height increases (0.76 and 0.27 standard deviation scores) with no significant side effects.
population_specificity: Seven pediatric patients (five girls, two boys, aged 2 years 7 months to 12 years) from unrelated Chinese families with SEDC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanical properties and failure mechanisms of type II collagen fibrils in tension, particularly in articular cartilage.
results_summary: The study identified two distinct failure mechanisms in type II collagen fibrils and found that network morphology significantly influences bulk mechanical response. The validated constitutive model improves the accuracy of finite element models for soft tissue analysis and enhances understanding of diseases like osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Isolated collagen networks from articular cartilage (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (mechanical testing, not a supplementation study).
study_duration: Not applicable (mechanical testing, not an intervention study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-arthritic mechanisms of Pueraria montana (PM) extract in a Type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) model.
results_summary: PM extract demonstrated anti-arthritic properties, reducing inflammation, toe swelling, and arthritis scores in CIA rats. It also inhibited MH7A cell proliferation, migration, and MMP secretion while promoting apoptosis.
population_specificity: CIA rats and TNF-α-stimulated MH7A cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sophoricoside (SOP) could reduce inflammation in type II collagen-induced arthritis by targeting NLRP3 signaling in macrophages.
results_summary: SOP reduced inflammatory activity and NLRP3, Caspase-1, and IL-1β protein levels in macrophages and alleviated RA symptoms in rats without liver or kidney toxicity, unlike triptolide (TP).
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats in a collagen-induced arthritis model and human THP-1-derived macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the paracrine effects of CPC-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) on native meniscal cells, particularly their role in promoting Type II Collagen mRNA expression and wound healing.
results_summary: CPC-EVs improved 2D wound healing and increased Type II Collagen mRNA expression in inner meniscal fibrochondrocytes, outperforming marrow stromal cell-derived EVs at an optimal dose of 1.0 × 10^7 particles/mL.
population_specificity: Human cartilage-derived progenitor cells (CPCs) and meniscal fibrochondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dendritic cells transfected with DNA constructs encoding type II collagen, IL-10, and CCR9 could induce immune tolerance and reduce arthritis severity in an experimental model.
results_summary: The study found that transfected dendritic cells reduced paw swelling, lowered antibodies to type II collagen, and improved histological joint changes in mice with arthritis, suggesting enhanced immune tolerance and reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice with antigen-collagen induced arthritis (ACIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which oral administration of undenatured type II collagen induces immune tolerance and protects against gut pathology and arthritis in a mouse model of Collagen-Induced Arthritis (CIA).
results_summary: Oral immune-therapy (OIT) with undenatured type II collagen reduced arthritis incidence by 50%, decreased IL-17 and IL-22 expression in joints, protected against gut damage, and modulated gut fucosylation and microbiome composition.
population_specificity: Mice with experimental Collagen-Induced Arthritis (CIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the Artneo complex containing undenatured chicken collagen type II in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that Artneo significantly reduced pain, stiffness, and improved joint function and quality of life compared to placebo, with a good safety profile. It was superior to placebo in all measured parameters.
population_specificity: 212 outpatients (171 women, 41 men) aged 40-75 with knee osteoarthritis (stages II-III Kellgren-Lawrence classification) from 12 centers in the Russian Federation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the genetic control of oral immune tolerance to Type-II Collagen in rheumatoid arthritis patients and its potential role in suppressing IFNγ production.
results_summary: The study identified SNP A-15,737 as associated with the ability of Type-II Collagen to suppress IFNγ production in stimulated RA PBMC, suggesting a genetic basis for oral tolerance. The findings were also explored in another autoimmune disease (dsSSc) with oral Type-I Collagen.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients with increased IFNγ production in vitro when PBMCs were cultured with Type-II Collagen.
effective_dosage: Low dose (30-70 µg/day) and High dose (90-130 µg/day), administered in 10-week increments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether acupuncture at ST36 and GB39 could mitigate protease activity, inflammation, and free radical damage in rats with Type-II Collagen-Induced Arthritis (CIA).
results_summary: Acupuncture reduced arthritis scores, inflammation, synovial hyperplasia, and angiogenesis while lowering TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6 mRNA levels. It also increased free radical clearance and SOD expression while decreasing ROS and MDA levels.
population_specificity: Type I CIA rats induced by Type-II collagen injection.
effective_dosage: Not specified (acupuncture administered 3 times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ferrous/ferric ions could enhance the crosslinking of type II collagen hydrogels to improve their mechanical properties, biocompatibility, and therapeutic efficacy in cartilage tissue regeneration for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that ferrous/ferric ions crosslinked type II collagen hydrogels exhibited enhanced mechanical strength, biocompatibility, and bioactivity, promoting cell proliferation, adhesion, and chondrogenic differentiation. Additionally, the hydrogels demonstrated potent anti-inflammatory effects and accelerated cartilage tissue regeneration in a rat model.
population_specificity: Rat model with cartilage defects (preclinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of WL-808, a near-infrared probe targeting type II collagen, for inhibiting heterotopic ossification (HO) development via photodynamic therapy (PDT).
results_summary: WL-808 effectively targeted type II collagen in HO, inducing chondrocyte apoptosis and inhibiting ectopic bone formation in mice, with no detected toxicity or side effects.
population_specificity: Tenotomy HO model mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the research progress of undenatured type II collagen, including its extraction methods, stability, and its role in improving osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: Undenatured type II collagen was found to reduce OA incidence and alleviate symptoms, though its activity is influenced by factors like source, denaturation degree, and dosage. The mechanism of action remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antistress and antioxidant effects of Ocimum sanctum (Tulsi) in albino rabbits subjected to chemically induced oxidative stress.
results_summary: O. sanctum supplementation reduced stress-induced changes in cardiorespiratory parameters, lowered blood sugar levels, and increased antioxidant enzyme activity (superoxide dismutase and reduced glutathione) while mitigating oxidative stress effects.
population_specificity: Albino rabbits
effective_dosage: 2 g fresh leaves per rabbit daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent knowledge on COL2 posttranslational modifications and their relevance to rheumatoid arthritis (RA) pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that COL2 posttranslational modifications play a significant role in RA autoimmunity, serving as neo-antigens that activate immune responses. Modified COL2 peptides were highlighted as a potential therapeutic strategy for RA.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral supplementation with protease-soluble chicken type II collagen (PSCC-II) could mitigate the progression of osteoarthritis (OA) induced by anterior cruciate ligament transection (ACLT) in rats.
results_summary: Rats treated with any form of type II collagen (C-II) showed significant reductions in pain sensitivity and cartilage degradation. PSCC-II and unproteolyzed C-II suppressed OA-related effects, such as inflammatory markers and cartilage damage, with PSCC-II providing superior benefits for OA management.
population_specificity: Eight-week-old male Wistar rats with ACLT-induced osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (groups included varying forms of C-II, but exact dosages were not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether type II collagen promotes chondrogenic differentiation in mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) as a potential therapeutic approach for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that type II collagen enhanced chondrogenic differentiation in both Wharton's jelly- and dental pulp-derived MSCs, as confirmed by gene and protein analysis of chondrogenic markers. The results suggest type II collagen acts as a natural bioscaffold to improve MSC-based therapies for cartilage regeneration.
population_specificity: Human Wharton's jelly- and dental pulp-derived mesenchymal stem cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a near-infrared (NIR) probe (WL-808) targeting type II collagen (Col2a1) for early diagnosis of heterotopic ossification (HO).
results_summary: WL-808 demonstrated high specificity for targeting HO cartilage lesions in vitro and in vivo, with no apparent cytotoxicity. The probe detected HO cartilage lesions as early as 1 week post-injury, before micro-CT could identify ectopic bone formation, and showed minimal distribution in normal knee articular cartilage.
population_specificity: Preclinical study (in vitro and in vivo models of heterotopic ossification).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a competitive chemiluminescence enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (CALC2) targeting the C-terminal pro-peptide of type II collagen as a biomarker for cartilage formation.
results_summary: The study found that CALC2 levels increased after BMP-1 cleavage of type II collagen and IGF-1 treatment in an ex vivo osteoarthritis model. CALC2 levels were lower in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis compared to healthy controls, suggesting its potential as a biomarker for type II collagen formation.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (18), ankylosing spondylitis (19), osteoarthritis (8), and age- and sex-matched healthy controls (32 total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and molecular mechanisms of undenatured type II collagen (UC-II) in treating osteoarthritis (OA), including its anti-inflammatory and chondroprotective effects.
results_summary: UC-II demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory and immunoregulatory effects, reducing proinflammatory cytokines and joint pain while improving joint function and mobility in OA patients. Clinical and preclinical studies supported its safety and efficacy, with no adverse effects on muscle structure under increased physical exertion.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (OA) and experimental models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immunomodulating nanoparticles loaded with Type-II Collagen and rapamycin could effectively treat osteoarthritis by inducing anti-inflammatory regulatory T cells and reducing joint inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that LNP-Col II-R injection induced Col II-specific anti-inflammatory regulatory T cells, increased anti-inflammatory cytokines, reduced inflammatory immune cells and proinflammatory cytokines, inhibited chondrocyte apoptosis and cartilage degradation, and relieved pain in OA mice. Control LNPs did not produce these effects.
population_specificity: OA mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic effects of ellagic acid (EA) in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rats.
results_summary: EA treatment significantly reduced inflammatory mediators (NF-kB, TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6) and oxidative stress markers, while increasing anti-inflammatory IL-10. It also mitigated TNF-α and CD8+ T cell expression in joint tissue, demonstrating potent anti-arthritic effects.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tulsi (Ocimum sanctum) combined with Vitamin E on biochemical parameters and retinopathy in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Treatment with Tulsi and Vitamin E significantly reduced plasma glucose, HbA1c, lipid profile, and lipid peroxidase (LPO) while increasing antioxidant enzymes (GPX, SOD, CAT, GST). Retinal improvements were observed via angiography after combined treatment.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic albino male rats (150-200 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of undenatured type II collagen (UC-II®), compared to cimicoxib and their combination, in reducing osteoarthritis symptoms in dogs.
results_summary: UC-II® significantly reduced LOAD, MOBILITY, and CLINICAL scores in osteoarthritic dogs, with comparable or superior efficacy to cimicoxib alone or in combination. The treatment groups showed statistically significant improvements over the control group.
population_specificity: Client-owned dogs with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of undenatured type II collagen (NEXT-II®) in improving joint and motor function in healthy Japanese adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in knee flexibility, mobility, and reductions in knee and lower back pain, as well as enhanced motor function with NEXT-II® supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese male and female participants aged 20 to <75 years.
effective_dosage: 3.2 mg/d of undenatured type II collagen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of Type-II Collagen peptides, among other compounds, on osteoarthritis (OA) in a rat model.
results_summary: Type-II Collagen peptides, along with chondroitin sulfate and cartilage powder, improved athletic ability in rats and reduced inflammatory cytokine levels in serum and synovial fluid. However, chondroitin sulfate demonstrated the best treatment effect against OA.
population_specificity: OA rat model induced by sodium iodoacetate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of native type II collagen (NC) when combined with glycosaminoglycans (CGH) in an osteoarthritis model, comparing its efficacy to CGH alone and a control group.
results_summary: CGH-NC (CS + GlHCl + HA + NC) showed significantly improved macroscopic and microscopic joint health compared to both the control and CGH alone, with additional benefits in synovial membrane values and MRI biomarkers. The study concluded that adding NC to CGH enhances efficacy in mitigating osteoarthritis-related degenerative changes.
population_specificity: 54 female 12-week-old New Zealand rabbits with induced osteoarthritis via cranial cruciate ligament transection.
study_duration: Subgroups assessed at 24, 56, and 84 days post-intervention.
